_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:
Fieldale Farms Corporation and our employees are committed to the safe and responsible operation and maintenance of our refrigeration process that uses anhydrous ammonia an OSHA classified hazardous substance.  Individual responsibilities are shown and described in our RMP Organizational Chart and RMP Management Duties which are reviewed yearly.  
Fieldale Farms uses a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to ensure the safety of our employees, the public and the protection of the environment.  The Executive Summary contains elements that we have designed and implemented including(1)A discription of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation(2)An overview of our accidental release prevention program(3)A five year accident history documenting accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia an EPA RMP regulated chemical(4)An overview of Fieldale Farms emergency response program(5)An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public and the environment. 
2.0  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES:   
Fieldale Farms Corporation processes poultry.  Anhydrous ammonia is used in the refrigeration equipment to keep the raw poultry cool or frozen during processing or storage.  Anhydrous ammonia has been identified by the EPA under the clean air ace Section 112(r) as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental relesase.  Our facility qualifies as a Risk Management Program 3 facility because we also are covered by OSHA's Process Safety Management(PSM) rule 29 CFR 1910.119.  
Toxics:  
Anhydrous ammonia is a toxic gas regulated by EPA under the clean air act section 112(r) Risk Management Program (RMP) rule.  Fieldale Farms Corporation has anhydrous ammonia in various interconnected vessels, piping and equipment w

hich make up our ammonia refrigeration system.  Our refrigeration system contains in excess of the 10,000 pound threshold quantity and is required to comply with 40 CFR 68 in addition to 29 CFR 1910.119.  Fieldale Farms accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public and the environment by our use of these chemicals.  
3.0  OFFSITE CONSEQUENCES ANALYSIS SCENARIOS:  
EPA's RMP rule requires that we conduct off-site consequence analysis for the worst-case accidental release and alternative accidental release scenarios regulated chemical, this has been done.  Worst-case and alternative release scenarios for regulated flammable chemicals are not applicable.  
5.0  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:  
Fieldale Farms keeps records of all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  Within the past five years, Fieldale Farms Corporation Cornelia Complex has not had a reportable accident involving anhydrous ammonia.   
6.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAMS:       
Fieldale Farms Corporation maintains an intergrated plan, which consolidates all of the various Federal, State and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the pubic and the environment during an emergency response.  Emergency response drills are conducted every 6 months by the Fieldale Farms emergency responders.  In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems, it is our policy to notify the National Response Center, the State EPD and by dialing 911, the local emergency responders.  Fieldale Farms request local agencies to respond to the emergency ammonia release, this has been discussed with the local Fire Departments and members of the Fire Department visited our facility.  
7.0  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:    
Fieldale Farms Corporat
ion has updated the ammonia process area and perimeter monitors therefore we have no plans to change our safety program at this time.
